answers.answer: Hi,Thanks for writing in.I can understand your agony but please realize it is very difficult to give a prognosis without examining the patient.Your mother does seem to be a lot of pain and has suffered extensive damage to her brain. It is very difficult to say if she will ever wake up. Please take a decision after discussing with your siblings and friends.Take care!

question: I'll start out by saying that my mom is a 59 year old woman who has been sick most of her life.  She has High blood pressure, diabetes and post polio syndrome.  She has also been battling sarcoidosis for over 20 years.  On August 29, 2008 my mom was found unresponsive at home.  She was believed to be sleeping but was actually unconscious and not breathing very well.  By the time she reached the ER she coded and it took about 5 minutes to restart her heart.  Since then she has not woken up.  She is not responsive  and she seems to be pretty lifeless.  She now has a tracheotomy and a feeding tube and the Doctors are telling me that the chances of her ever coming back are nill.  She has only had and EEG and a CAT SCAN and today they told me that she would never breath again on her own because her brain stem is totally damaged.  She has some minimal cerebral functions but not much.  They are suggesting that I sign a DNR and consider putting her on comfort care  so that she can pass peacefully.  Her eyes are always wide open and blinking rapidly and she keeps opening her mouth wide (like a yawn) and the Doctors tell me that all of those things exhibit her feeling pain.  Is this so?  I am so confused and I dont know what to do.  Do I keep her on the machines and pray for a miracle or do I just let her go peacefully?  Is it possible to come back from this?  Please help if you can.  any help would be greatly appreciated.
title: Oxygen loss to the brain
